qas.question: The algorithm defining artificial viscosity is a fundamental contribution to what area?
What did the math of artificial viscosity do?

answers.text: smoothed the shock transition without sacrificing basic physics

qas.question: What was the problem of computers solving fluid dynamics?

answers.text: they tried to put too many computational grid points at regions of sharp discontinuity (shock waves)

context: Von Neumann made fundamental contributions in exploration of problems in <a0_0>numerical hydrodynamics<a0_0/>. For example, with Robert D. Richtmyer he developed an algorithm defining artificial viscosity that improved the understanding of shock waves. A problem was that when computers solved hydrodynamic or aerodynamic problems, <a2_0>they tried to put too many computational grid points at regions of sharp discontinuity (shock waves)<a2_0/>. The mathematics of artificial viscosity <a1_0>smoothed the shock transition without sacrificing basic physics<a1_0/>. Other well known contributions to fluid dynamics included the classic flow solution to blast waves, and the co-discovery of the ZND detonation model of explosives.
